title: 109_hr3267
content: The Act may be cited as the "Domestic Partnership Benefits and Obligations Act" and provides benefits to domestic partners of federal employees. The "Domestic Partnership Benefits and Obligations Act" grants benefits to domestic partners of federal employees, who must file an affidavit certifying their relationship and eligibility criteria. The "Domestic Partnership Benefits and Obligations Act" requires federal employees and their domestic partners to file an affidavit certifying their relationship and eligibility criteria, including being same-sex or opposite-sex partners not prohibited from legal marriage in their state. Willful falsification may result in disciplinary action and the recovery of benefits received. If the partnership dissolves, a statement must be filed with the Office of Personnel Management within 30 days. The "Domestic Partnership Benefits and Obligations Act" requires federal employees and their domestic partners to file an affidavit certifying their relationship and eligibility criteria. If the partnership dissolves, benefits received by the domestic partner will terminate, except in cases of the employee's death. The "Domestic Partnership Benefits and Obligations Act" states that if a partnership dissolves by a method other than death, health benefits for the domestic partner will continue for 60 days. Information submitted for benefits certification must be kept confidential. The term "domestic partner" refers to an adult person in a committed relationship living with another adult person but not married. "Benefits" include compensation for work injuries, retirement benefits, life insurance, and health insurance under specific chapters of the United States Code. The term "employee" is defined accordingly. The term "employee" is defined based on specific sections of the United States Code for different benefits. "Obligations" refer to duties or responsibilities that would be incurred by an employee's spouse. SEC. 3. EXEMPTION FROM TAX FOR EMPLOYER-PROVIDED FRINGE BENEFITS TO DOMESTIC PARTNERS. Amends Section 106 of the Internal Revenue Code to include domestic partners in the provisions of the Domestic Partnership Benefits and Obligations Act for tax exemption on fringe benefits. Effective for taxable years starting after December 31, 2005.
